<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D162447D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	from &#128;6.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 to &#128;35.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, mainly due to increased non-cash stock-based
	compensation expense. In addition, purchases and external expenses increased by &#128;8.5&nbsp;million, from &#128;6.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 to &#128;15.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, due
	to increased expenses related to innovation and platform development, including payments to third-parties participating in product development, purchases of biological raw materials and expenses associated with the use of laboratories and other
	facilities. Other expenses, which relate to continuing leasing and other commitments, increased from &#128;1.2&nbsp;million to &#128;1.7&nbsp;million during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded &#128;17.8&nbsp;million and &#128;14.4&nbsp;million, respectively, in
	research and development expenses. This decrease of &#128;3.4&nbsp;million, or 19.3%, was primarily attributable to a &#128;3.0&nbsp;million decrease in purchases and external expenses resulting from the winding down of the Tools and Services
	segment and the discontinuation of its operations (other than the run-off of legacy contracts).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded &#128;13.1&nbsp;million and
	&#128;27.2&nbsp;million, respectively, in selling, general and administrative expenses. The increase of &#128;14.1&nbsp;million, or 107.7%, primarily reflects an increase of &#128;14.1&nbsp;million in personnel expenses, from &#128;5.5&nbsp;million
	to &#128;19.6&nbsp;million, attributable, among other things, to (i) &#128;11.6&nbsp;million of non-cash stock-based compensation expense in 2015 from &#128;0.3&nbsp;million in 2014, and to (ii) &#128;4.5&nbsp;million of social charges on stock
	options and free share grants from &#128;0.1&nbsp;million in 2014. In addition, purchases and external expenses increased by &#128;0.7&nbsp;million from &#128;5.4&nbsp;million in 2014 to &#128;6.1&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily with respect to
	professional costs associated with our U.S. IPO on the Nasdaq Stock Exchange in March 2015. Other expenses decreased from &#128;2.2&nbsp;million for 2014 to &#128;1.5&nbsp;million for 2015, a decrease reflecting a grant provision that was booked in
	2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded &#128;19.0&nbsp;million and &#128;13.1&nbsp;million,
	respectively, in selling, general and administrative expenses. The decrease of &#128;5.9&nbsp;million, or 31.1%, primarily reflects (1)&nbsp;a decrease of personnel expenses of &#128;2.4&nbsp;million due to headcount reduction, (2)&nbsp;a decrease
	of &#128;3.1&nbsp;million in legal fees, as we settled an intellectual property dispute at the end of 2013, and (3)&nbsp;a decrease of &#128;1.7&nbsp;million related to non-recurring set-up costs incurred in 2013 in connection with the establishment
	of Sc&eacute;il, an iPS stem cell entity. These reductions were partially offset by a provision of &#128;1.1&nbsp;million related to the reimbursement of a research grant.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, we recorded &#128;0.8&nbsp;million in other operating income,
	which included income from (i)&nbsp;the reversal of a subsidy provision, (ii)&nbsp;the reversal of lease incentives deferrals, and (iii)&nbsp;a gain from a settlement with a supplier. We did not record any other operating income for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, we recorded &#128;0.5&nbsp;million in other operating income, which
	primarily reflected income as a result of the reversal of litigation provisions.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded &#128;0.5&nbsp;million in expenses and
	&#128;0.2&nbsp;million in net income, respectively, with respect to our redundancy plan. The &#128;0.2&nbsp;million of net income recorded in 2015 resulted from the reversal of unutilized redundancy plan reserves.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded &#128;1.9&nbsp;million and &#128;0.5&nbsp;million, respectively, in
	redundancy plan expenses. The 2013 redundancy plan expense reflected the winding-down of our Tools and Services segment as well as our decision to discontinue some of our research and development programs. The 2014 redundancy plan expense related to
	the cost of a second redundancy plan implemented in July 2014.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded &#128;0.6&nbsp;million and
	&#128;3.2&nbsp;million, respectively, in other operating expenses. This increase is mainly due to settlements and increases in various reserves.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded &#128;0.4&nbsp;million and &#128;0.6&nbsp;million, respectively, in other
	operating expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Financial revenues.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded &#128;7.6&nbsp;million and
	&#128;9.2&nbsp;million, respectively, in financial revenues. The increase of &#128;1.6&nbsp;million, or 21.3%, was mainly attributable to the significant foreign exchange gain for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, which resulted from the
	translation of our U.S.&nbsp;Dollar-denominated cash and cash equivalent into Euro at the closing rate for the period, generating an &#128;8.2&nbsp;million gain compared to a &#128;7.1&nbsp;million gain in 2014. Additionally, interest income
	increased from &#128;0.3&nbsp;million in 2014 to &#128;1.0&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014,
	we recorded &#128;0.5&nbsp;million and &#128;7.6&nbsp;million, respectively, in financial revenues. The increase of &#128;7.1&nbsp;million, or 1,528.6%, reflects foreign exchange gains on our U.S.&nbsp;Dollar-denominated bank accounts related to the
	$80.0 million upfront payment from Pfizer received in August 2014. From this date to December&nbsp;31, 2014, the U.S.&nbsp;Dollar exchange rate versus the Euro increased by approximately 10.4%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:6%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded &#128;0.5&nbsp;million and
	&#128;1.7&nbsp;million, respectively, in financial expenses. The increase of &#128;1.2&nbsp;million, or 220.7%, was mainly attributable to a foreign exchange loss of &#128;1.5 million in 2015.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded &#128;1.9&nbsp;million in income from
	continuing operations and a &#128;20.4&nbsp;million loss from continuing operations, respectively. The decrease of &#128;22.2&nbsp;million, or 1,201.3%, was primarily related to a &#128;30.1&nbsp;million increase in non-cash stock-based compensation
	expense and a &#128;12.2&nbsp;million increase in social charges on stock options and free share grants, partially offset by an increase of &#128;29.9&nbsp;million in revenues and other income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded a &#128;26.8&nbsp;million loss from continuing operations and
	&#128;1.9&nbsp;million in income from continuing operations, respectively. The improvement of &#128;28.7&nbsp;million, or 106.9%, resulted from the factors described above with respect to financial revenues and financial expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Loss from discontinued operations.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="67%">
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded &#128;29.6&nbsp;million and
	&#128;2.8&nbsp;million, respectively, in loss from discontinued operations. The decrease of &#128;26.8&nbsp;million, or 90.5%, primarily reflects an impairment expense that we recognized in connection with the winding-down of our operations in the
	Tools and Services segment in 2013. The loss from discontinued operations in 2014 primarily was generated by Cellectis AB.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded &#128;1.0&nbsp;million in loss
	attributable to non-controlling interests and &#128;0.2&nbsp;million in gain attributable to non-controlling interests, respectively. Notably, non-controlling interests for 2015 include 25% of the income of Cellectis Bioresearch and its subsidiaries
	until our repurchase from &#147;
<I>
	Caisse des D&eacute;p&ocirc;ts et Consignations
</I>
	&#148; on May&nbsp;18, 2015 of its shares, which represented the entirety of this non-controlling interest.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During each of the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded &#128;1.0&nbsp;million of loss attributable to non-controlling
	interests.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Segment Results
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Information related to each of our reportable segments is set out below. Segment Revenues and Other income, Research and Development expenses,
	Selling, General and administrative expenses, Royalties and other operating income and expenses, and Operating profit or loss (without non-cash stock-based expenses) are used by the CODM to measure segment performance. Segment operating profit or
	loss includes the impact of the operations between separate segments, while the intra-segment operations are eliminated. We do not focus on any asset or liability information by segment or region to measure performance.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	124
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage132"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D162447D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	There are intersegment transactions between the two reportable segments, including allocations of
	(i)&nbsp;corporate general and administrative expenses and (ii)&nbsp;research and development expenses to our subsidiaries. These intersegment expenses are priced at cost, plus a mark-up of 4-10%, depending on the nature of the service.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, 2014 and 2015
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with our ordinary course annual procedures, the Company identified certain immaterial errors in revenue recognition related to
	license contracts signed in 2012 and 2013 in our Plants segment. While nonrefundable upfront payments received were fully recognized in revenues at the contract dates, these payments should instead have been recognized over the license periods
	provided for by the contracts. Adjustments to prior periods are immaterial and therefore have been recorded in the Statement of Consolidated Operations in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. The cumulative adjustment recorded was
	&#128;0.8&nbsp;million at the end of 2015. Had corrections been recorded contemporaneously, Plant segment revenue and other income would have been &#128;0.5&nbsp;million in 2013, &#128;1.1&nbsp;million in 2014 and &#128;1.1&nbsp;million in 2015. The
	table below shows segment results.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Therapeutics segment&#151;2014 vs. 2015
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded external revenues and other income of &#128;25.4&nbsp;million and
	&#128;56.3&nbsp;million, respectively. This &#128;30.1&nbsp;million increase primarily reflects increased revenues under our collaboration agreements with Servier and Pfizer, including revenue of &#128;18.8&nbsp;million received in connection with
	the amendment to our collaboration agreement with Servier, which was signed on November&nbsp;18, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded total operating expenses of &#128;29.7&nbsp;million and &#128;79.2&nbsp;million, respectively. This increase of &#128;49.5&nbsp;million resulted primarily from higher personnel expenses attributable,
	among other things, to increases in non-cash stock-based compensation expenses, social charges on stock options and free shares grants, and professional costs. The increase also reflects an increase of &#128;35.7&nbsp;million in research and
	development expenses, &#128;13.3&nbsp;million in selling, general and administrative expenses and &#128;0.5 million in royalties and other operating income and expenses, year-over-year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded operating loss before tax of &#128;4.3&nbsp;million and
	&#128;22.9&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	125
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage133"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D162447D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Therapeutics segment&#151;2013 vs. 2014
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded external revenues and other income of &#128;11.4&nbsp;million and
	&#128;25.4&nbsp;million, respectively. This &#128;13.9&nbsp;million increase primarily reflects revenues under our collaboration agreements with Servier and Pfizer, which were signed in February 2014 and June 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded total operating expenses of &#128;37.0&nbsp;million and
	&#128;29.7&nbsp;million, respectively. This decrease of &#128;7.3&nbsp;million reflects a decrease of &#128;2.9&nbsp;million in research and development expenses and &#128;5.9&nbsp;million in selling, general and administrative expenses,
	year-over-year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded operating loss before tax of &#128;25.5&nbsp;million and
	&#128;4.3&nbsp;million, respectively. This decrease of &#128;21.2&nbsp;million resulted primarily from the increase in revenues and from the winding-down of the Tools and Services segment and from a reduction of administrative expenses, and an
	increase of &#128;1.6 million in royalties and other income and expenses as a result of lower professional fees and non-recurrence of expenses related to establishment of Sc&eacute;il operations in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Plants segment&#151;2014 vs. 2015
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded external revenues and other income of &#128;1.06&nbsp;million and
	&#128;44&nbsp;thousand, respectively, a &#128;1,021&nbsp;thousand decrease.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we
	recorded total operating expenses of &#128;2.0&nbsp;million and &#128;5.1&nbsp;million, respectively. This increase of &#128;3.1&nbsp;million reflects an increase of &#128;2.3&nbsp;million in research and development expenses and
	&#128;0.8&nbsp;million in selling, general and administrative expenses, year-over-year, in each case as a result of increased employee expenses and outsourcing expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015, we recorded operating loss before tax of &#128;1.0&nbsp;million and
	&#128;5.1&nbsp;million, respectively. This increase of &#128;4.1&nbsp;million resulted primarily from the above-mentioned increases in operating expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Plants segment&#151;2013 vs. 2014
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded external revenues and other income of &#128;1.3&nbsp;million and
	&#128;1.1&nbsp;million, respectively a decrease of &#128;0.2 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, we recorded
	total operating expenses of &#128;2.3&nbsp;million and &#128;2.0&nbsp;million, respectively. This decrease of &#128;0.3&nbsp;million primarily reflects a decrease of &#128;0.5&nbsp;million in research and development expenses, and an increase of
	&#128;0.2 million in royalties and other operating income and expenses, year-over-year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and
	2014, we recorded operating loss before tax of &#128;1.0&nbsp;million and &#128;0.9&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	B.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Introduction
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have incurred losses and cumulative negative cash flows from operations since our inception in 2000, and we anticipate that we will continue
	to incur losses for at least the next several years. We expect that our research and development and selling, general and administrative expenses will continue to increase and, as a result, we will need additional capital to fund our operations,
	which we may raise through a combination of equity offerings, debt financings, other third-party funding, marketing and distribution arrangements and other collaborations, strategic alliances and licensing arrangements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	126
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage134"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D162447D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have funded our operations since inception primarily through private and public offerings of
	our equity securities, grant revenues, payments received under patent licenses, reimbursements of research tax credit claims and payments under our strategic alliances with Pfizer and Servier. Our ordinary shares have been traded on the Alternext
	market of Euronext in Paris since February&nbsp;7, 2007 and our ADSs have traded on the Nasdaq Global Market in New York since March&nbsp;30, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Key Liquidity Events
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	2013&#151;
</I>
	We realized cash proceeds of &#128;2.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 through the issuance and sale of ordinary shares pursuant to employee and non-employee warrants.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	2014&#151;
</I>
	In March 2014, we completed a private placement of 4,000,000 ordinary shares to institutional investors for gross proceeds of &#128;20.5 million. In July 2014, in connection with our collaboration
	agreement with Pfizer, we issued 2,786,924 ordinary shares, representing 10% of our then-outstanding ordinary shares, to Pfizer for gross proceeds of &#128;25.8 million. In November 2014, we issued shares in connection with the exercise of
	non-employee warrants for gross proceeds of &#128;13.4 million.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<I>
	2015&#151;
</I>
	In March 2015, we completed our U.S. initial public offering of ADSs on the Nasdaq for gross of $228 million of gross proceeds, of which we received net proceeds of $209.6 million.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had cash and cash equivalents of &#128;314.2 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Liquidity management
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash in excess of
	immediate requirements is invested in accordance with our investment policy, primarily with a view to liquidity and capital preservation. Currently, our funds are held in bank accounts, money market funds and fixed bank deposits primarily in France
	and is primarily denominated in U.S. Dollars ($283.0 million as of December&nbsp;31, 2015).
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2015
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We had net cash flows provided by operating activities of continuing operations of &#128;3.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2015, primarily as a result of payments received from Servier and, to a lesser extent, Pfizer. In December 2015, we received an upfront payment of &#128;35.6&nbsp;million in connection with the amendment to our collaboration agreement with Servier.
	Our cash expenditures during 2015 related to our research and development efforts, including the advancement of UCART19, for which a CTA was filed in the United Kingdom in 2015. Cash outflows for 2015 also include &#128;12.2&nbsp;million of social
	charges on free shares and stock options grants.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The net cash flows used in investing activities of continuing operations of
	&#128;7.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 primarily reflects our use of &#128;3.8&nbsp;million for the acquisition of industrial and laboratory equipment at Cellectis S.A. and Cellectis Inc., and our repurchase for
	&#128;3.5&nbsp;million of 25% of the minority shares of Cellectis Bioresearch.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	127
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage135"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D162447D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The net cash flows provided by financing activities of continuing operations of
	&#128;198.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 includes the net proceeds from our U.S. initial public offering on the Nasdaq Global Market in March 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We had net cash flows used in operating activities of continuing operations &#128;19.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013
	versus net cash provided by operating activities of continuing operations of &#128;42.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. Substantially all of our cash expenditures during these years related to our research and development
	efforts, including the advancement of the pre-clinical development of UCART19. The increase in cash flows provided by operating activities of continuing operations during 2014 is primarily due to payments received from Servier and Pfizer pursuant to
	our collaboration agreements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The net cash flows used in investing activities of continuing operations was &#128;459 thousand for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 compared to net cash used in investing activities of continuing operations of &#128;1.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. During both years, these amounts include the acquisitions of industrial
	and laboratory equipment required to conduct our research programs, as well as changes in non-current financial assets and liabilities. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, cash provided by investing activities of continuing operations also
	includes the proceeds from the sale of Cellectis AB.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The net cash flows provided by financing activities of continuing operations were
	&#128;5.2&nbsp;million and &#128;57.9&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2014, respectively. The amount in 2014 includes proceeds from the issuance and sale of ordinary shares to institutional investors in March 2014, to
	Pfizer in July 2014, and in connection with the exercise of non-employees warrants in November 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Conditional Advances
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have benefited from multiple conditional advances from BpiFrance, formerly named OSEO Innovation, which do not accrue interest and whose
	repayments are conditional on the technical and/or commercial success of our products. As of December&nbsp;31, 2014, we had a total of &#128;3.4&nbsp;million of outstanding conditional advances. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had a total of
	&#128;1.8&nbsp;million of outstanding conditional advances. We expect them to be repaid before December 2016. For further details of these conditional advances, see Note 13.2 to our audited consolidated financial statements for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Operating capital requirements
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	To date, we have not generated any revenues from therapeutic or agricultural product sales. We do not know when, or if, we will generate any
	revenues from product sales. We do not expect to generate significant revenues from product sales unless and until we obtain regulatory approval of and commercialize one of our current or future product candidates. We anticipate that we will
	continue to generate losses for the foreseeable future, and we expect the losses to increase as we continue the development of, and seek regulatory approvals for, our product candidates, and begin to commercialize any approved products. We are
	subject to all risks incident in the development of new gene therapy products, and we may encounter unforeseen expenses, difficulties, complications, delays and other unknown factors that may adversely affect our business. We are also subject to all
	risks incident in the development of new agricultural products, and we may encounter unforeseen expenses, difficulties, complications, delays and other unknown factors that may adversely affect our business. We expect to continue to incur additional
	costs associated with operating as a public company in the United States. We also anticipate increased expenses related to audit, legal, regulatory and tax-related services associated with our public company obligations in the United States and our
	continued compliance with applicable U.S. exchange listing and SEC requirements. We anticipate that we will need substantial additional funding in connection with our continuing operations, including for the further development of our existing
	product candidates and to pursue other development activities related to additional product candidates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	128
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage136"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D162447D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We believe our cash and cash equivalents, our cash flow from operations (including payments we
	expect to receive pursuant to our collaboration agreements) and government funding of research programs will be sufficient to fund our operations through at least 2018. However, we may require additional capital for the further development of our
	existing product candidates and may also need to raise additional funds sooner to pursue other development activities related to additional product candidates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Until we can generate a sufficient amount of revenues from our products, if ever, we expect to finance a portion of future cash needs through
	public or private equity or debt offerings. Additional capital may not be available on reasonable terms, if at all. If we are unable to raise additional capital in sufficient amounts or on terms acceptable to us, we may have to significantly delay,
	scale back or discontinue the development or commercialization of one or more of our product candidates. If we raise additional funds through the issuance of additional debt or equity securities, it could result in dilution to our existing
	shareholders, increased fixed payment obligations and these securities may have rights senior to those of our ordinary shares. If we incur indebtedness, we could become subject to covenants that would restrict our operations and potentially impair
	our competitiveness, such as limitations on our ability to incur additional debt, limitations on our ability to acquire, sell or license intellectual property rights and other operating restrictions that could adversely impact our ability to conduct
	our business. Any of these events could significantly harm our business, financial condition and prospects.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our forecast of the period of
	time through which our financial resources will be adequate to support our operations is a forward-looking statement and involves risks and uncertainties, and actual results could vary as a result of a number of factors. We have based this estimate
	on assumptions that may prove to be wrong, and we could use our available capital resources sooner than we currently expect. Our future funding requirements, both near and long-term, will depend on many factors, including, but not limited to:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the initiation, progress, timing, costs and results of pre-clinical and clinical studies for our product candidates;
</TD>
</TR>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the ability of our product candidates to progress through clinical development successfully;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	If we cannot expand our operations or otherwise capitalize on our business opportunities because we lack sufficient capital, our business,
	financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D162447D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	C.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Research and Development, Patents and Licenses, etc.
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our research and development teams
	utilize our deep expertise to contribute to the growth of our business. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had 82 employees engaged in research and development activities. In the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, 2014 and 2015 we spent
	&#128;17.8&nbsp;million, &#128;14.4&nbsp;million and &#128;52.4&nbsp;million, respectively, on research and development. For a discussion of our research and development activities, see &#147;Item 4.B&#151;Business Overview&#148; and &#147;Item
	5.A&#151;Operating Results.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	D.

	Trend Information
</B>

</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For a discussion of trends, see &#147;Item 4.B&#151;Business
	Overview,&#148; &#147;Item 5.A&#151;Operating Results&#148; and &#147;Item 5.B&#151;Liquidity and Capital Resources.&#148; Other than as disclosed in these sections, we are not aware of any trends, uncertainties, demands, commitments or events since
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 that are reasonably likely to have a material adverse effect on our revenues, income, profitability, liquidity or capital resources, or that would cause the disclosed financial information to be not necessarily indicative of
	future operating results or financial condition.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The commitment amounts in the table above are associated with contracts that are enforceable and legally
	binding and that specify all significant terms, including fixed or minimum services to be used, fixed, minimum or variable price provisions, and the approximate timing of the actions under the contracts. The table does not include obligations under
	agreements that we can cancel without a significant penalty. We have collaboration agreements whereby we are obligated to pay royalties and milestones based on future events that are uncertain and therefore they are not included in the table above.
</P>

</EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Andr&eacute; Choulika
</I>
</B>
	, Ph.D., is one of the founders of Cellectis and has been our Chairman of
	the Board and Chief Executive Officer since 2000. He has also been President of Calyxt, Inc. since August 2010. From 1997 to 1999, Dr.&nbsp;Choulika worked as a post-doctoral fellow in the Division of Molecular Medicine at Boston Children&#146;s
	Hospital, where he was a pioneer in the analysis and use of meganucleases to modify complex genomes. He has also served on the boards of directors of several biotechnology companies. After receiving his PhD in molecular virology from the University
	of Paris VI (Pierre et Marie Curie), he completed a research fellowship in the Harvard Medical School Department of Genetics. Dr.&nbsp;Choulika also has management training from the HEC (Challenge +). Based on Dr.&nbsp;Choulika&#146;s deep knowledge
	of the company and scientific experience, we believe Dr.&nbsp;Choulika has the appropriate set of skills to serve as our chief executive officer and a member of our board of directors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Mathieu Simon
</I>
</B>
	, M.D., has served as a director since June&nbsp;14, 2013, as Executive Vice-President since 2012 and as Chief
	Operating Officer since 2013. Dr.&nbsp;Simon was the Director and Chairman of the Board of Cellectis AB from 2013 to 2014 and has been a Director of Ectycell. Prior to joining us, from 2000 to 2010 Dr.&nbsp;Simon was Senior Vice President Head of
	Global Pharmaceutical Operations at Pierre Fabre SA. From 1994 to 2010, Dr.&nbsp;Simon led several Wyeth subsidiaries as General Manager (including Italy and Belgium). From 1994 to 1997, he served as Group Vice President of Marketing and Clinical
	Affairs for Wyeth International in Philadelphia, USA. From 2000 and 2010, Dr.&nbsp;Simon was a Director of Wyeth S.p.A., Farmindustria, and Pharma in Italy. Dr.&nbsp;Simon graduated from medical school at the University of Paris in 1982.
	Dr.&nbsp;Simon today is an advisor at the European Commission D.G. Research and Innovation (Horizon 2020). We believe Dr.&nbsp;Simon&#146;s extensive business and leadership experience in the pharmaceutical industry qualifies him to serve as a
	member of our board of directors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	David Sourdive
</I>
</B>
	, Ph.D., is a co-founder of Cellectis and has held the position of
	Executive Vice President, Corporate Development since 2008. Dr.&nbsp;Sourdive has also been a member of our board of directors since 2000. From 2009 to 2012, he served as President of Ectycell SAS, and since 2012, he has served on its supervisory
	committee. Since February 2014, Dr.&nbsp;Sourdive has also served on the board of directors of Mediterranean Institute for Life Sciences, and since June 2015, he has served on the board of directors of Eukar&yuml;s SAS. He previously
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	131
</P>

</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	served on the boards of directors of Cellectis AB, Medicen Paris Region and Seine Saint Denis Avenir. From 1998 to 2000, he directed the biotechnologies laboratory of the Centre d&#146;Etudes du
	Bouchet for the French Ministry of Defense. From 1997 to 1998, Dr.&nbsp;Sourdive worked at one of the leading laboratories in viral immunology at Emory University in Atlanta, Georgia. His work there was focused on immunological T-cell memory.
	Dr.&nbsp;Sourdive graduated from the &Eacute;cole Polytechnique and received his PhD in molecular virology at the Institut Pasteur. He also has management training from the HEC (Challenge +). We believe Dr.&nbsp;Sourdive&#146;s extensive experience
	in business and the biotechnology industry qualifies him to serve on our board of directors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Philippe Duchateau
</I>
</B>
	, Ph.D.,
	joined Cellectis in 2001 to pioneer the field of genome engineering and has served as Chief Scientific Officer since 2012. After receiving his PhD in 1993 in biochemistry and molecular biology at the Institut Pasteur (Lille, France), he completed a
	research fellowship from 1993 to 2001 at the University of California, San Francisco (United States) within the Cardiovascular Research Institute. He is co-inventor of numerous patents in the field of nucleases and genome engineering and co-authors
	on more than 50 scientific publications and co-editor of one book entitled &#147;Site-directed Insertion of Transgenes.&#148; As head of Cellectis&#146;s Research department since 2004, he helped to the development of the Cellectis Technologies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Eric Dutang
</I>
</B>
	joined us as Deputy Chief Financial Officer in May 2015 and was appointed Chief Financial Officer in 2016. Eric
	began his career as financial auditor with KPMG, first in Paris for five years and then in New York for two years. He worked for listed companies in France and the United States such as Vivendi, Veolia Environnement or Cablevision. He then became a
	member of the transactions and advisory teams in Paris for seven years where he carried out acquisitions / disposals for listed companies and private equity funds. After serving at KPMG, he worked on international business developments for French
	public listed groups, including Air Liquide and Thales. Eric holds a Master of Finance and Executive MBA from HEC Paris (France)/Babson Massachusetts (USA).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Luc Mathis
</I>
</B>
	, Ph.D., has been Chief Executive Officer of Calyxt, Inc. since 2012. He previously served as Business Development
	Director of Cellectis from 2006 to 2011. From 2001 to 2005, he was a research scientist at Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique. After receiving his PhD in developmental biology at the Pasteur Institute in 1997, he completed post-doctoral
	studies at the California Institute of Technology from 1998 to 2000. Mr.&nbsp;Mathis previously served on the board of directors of the Association Fran&ccedil;aise de Biotechnologies Vegetales and currently serves on the board of directors of the
	French-American Chamber of Commerce in Minneapolis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Julia Berretta
</I>
</B>
	, Ph.D., joined Cellectis in 2010 in the scientific
	alliance and business development department. She has served as VP Business Development and Strategic Planning since 2014. Prior to joining Cellectis, she worked as a researcher at the CNRS in Gif-sur-Yvette. Julia Berretta received her Ph.D. in
	molecular biology from the Universit&eacute; Paris XI, and holds a specialized Master&#146;s Degree in innovation management from Neoma Business School.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Marie-Bleuenn Terrier
</I>
</B>
	joined Cellectis as Legal Counsel in 2008, and was appointed General Counsel in 2013. Prior to joining
	Cellectis, she worked as Legal Counsel for Pfizer from 2004 to 2006, and for Boehringer from 2006 to 2008. Marie-Bleuenn Terrier has also served as Secretary of our board of directors since 2015. She holds a Master&#146;s degree in Law from the
	Panth&eacute;on La Sorbonne University in Paris.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Alain Godard
</I>
</B>
	has served as a member of our board of directors since
	October 2007. Since 2002, Mr.&nbsp;Godard has been a consultant in plant biotechnology and management. He has been the Chief Executive Officer of SARL Godard&nbsp;&amp; Co. and has served on its board of directors since June 2009. He previously
	served as chairman of the management board of Aventis Cropscience from 1999 to 2001 and served on the executive committee of Aventis Cropscience for the same period. He held several executive positions at Rh&ocirc;ne-Poulenc Agrochimie since joining
	in 1975, and he became CEO of the company in 1991 and chairman and CEO in 1995. Mr.&nbsp;Godard was appointed to the executive committee of the Rh&ocirc;ne-Poulenc group in 1997, where he oversaw operations in the field of animal and plant health
	and the group&#146;s Asia region. In 1999 he was an active player in the merger of Hoechst and Rh&ocirc;ne-Poulenc, which resulted in the founding of Aventis. Mr.&nbsp;Godard is a graduate of the &Eacute;cole Nationale Sup&eacute;rieure Agronomique
	de Toulouse. He began his agronomy career in 1967 in Africa as a researcher at the l&#146;Institut de Recherche pour les Huiles et Ol&eacute;agineux (institute for research on oils and oleaginous plants). We believe Mr.&nbsp;Godard&#146;s leadership
	and management experience in the plant biotechnology field qualifies him to serve as a member of our board of directors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">

<B>
<I>
	Pierre Bastid
</I>
</B>
	has served as a member of our board of directors since
	October&nbsp;28, 2011. He has been a member of the board of directors of HOUGOU S.A. since May&nbsp;23, 2011. He also currently serves on the boards of directors of HOUGOU D&eacute;veloppement S.A., Louise 342-344 S.A., Crystal Sunrise S.A., Shango
	S.A., Hebioso S.A., Nepteam S.A.S., La Chartreuse B S.C., Pharnext S.A.S., Batuque Hotelaria e Turismo S.A., Casino Royal S.A. and The Juilliard School. From 2005 to 2011, he served as the President and Chief Executive Officer of Converteam Group
	S.A.S. (formerly Alstom Power Conversion). From June 2011 to July 2014, he was also a member of board of directors of Zaka S.A. From 2008 to 2011, Mr.&nbsp;Bastid served as President and a member of the board of directors of CVT Holding S.A.S. and
	as President of Financi&egrave;re CVT S.A.S. From 2009 to 2011, he served as President of CMC Kilimanjaro, CMC Everest, CMC Mac Kinley, CMC Elbrouz and CMC K2. He was a Manager at Damballah S.C. from 2011 to 2012. We believe Mr.&nbsp;Bastid&#146;s
	extensive business experience qualifies him to serve as a member on our board of directors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Laurent Arthaud
</I>
</B>
	has served as a
	member of our board of directors since October&nbsp;28, 2011. Mr.&nbsp;Arthaud has been the Managing Director of Life Sciences and Ecotechnologies for Bpifrance Investissement (formerly CDC Enterprises, a subsidiary of Caisse des
	D&eacute;p&ocirc;ts) since 2012. He currently serves on the boards of directors of Kurma Life Sciences Partners, TxCell, Adocia and Emertec Gestion. From 2006 to 2012, Mr.&nbsp;Arthaud held the position of Deputy CEO at CDC Entreprises. Since 2009
	Mr.&nbsp;Arthaud has also directed InnoBio, an investment fund managed by Bpifrance Investissement as part of the FSI France Investissement program. From 1999 to 2004 he served as Vice President of Aventis Capital, an investment subsidiary of the
	pharmaceuticals group Aventis, and as President of Pharmavent Partners from 2004 to 2006. Mr.&nbsp;Arthaud is a graduate of the &Eacute;cole Polytechnique and the &Eacute;cole Nationale de Statistique et d&#146;Administration &Eacute;conomique. We
	believe Mr.&nbsp;Arthaud&#146;s extensive investment experience in the biotechnology industry qualifies him to serve as a member on our board of directors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Annick Schwebig
</I>
</B>
	, M.D., has served as a member of our board of directors since October&nbsp;28, 2011. In 2000, she founded the
	French subsidiary of Actelion, of which she is a Senior Advisor. She formerly served as the General Manager of Actelion from 2000 to 2015. Actelion is a biopharmaceuticals company specializing in innovative treatments to serve unmet medical needs.
	She is also President of the Biotechnologies Committee within the LEEM (French Pharmaceutical Industry Association&#146;s) since 2000, which coordinates studies on cell therapies and nanomedicine, as well as General Secretary of the Alliance for
	Research and Innovation in Health Industries (ARIIS). A graduate of the University of Paris medical school, Dr.&nbsp;Schwebig worked as a senior manager at the biopharmaceuticals company Bristol-Myers Squibb for 17 years from 1983 to 2000. We
	believe Dr.&nbsp;Schwebig&#146;s extensive experience in the biopharmaceutical industry qualifies her to serve as a member on our board of directors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Jean-Marie Messier
</I>
</B>
	has served as a member of our board of directors since May&nbsp;18, 2015. He is co-founder and head of
	Messier Maris&nbsp;&amp; Associ&eacute;s, an international investment banking firm. Mr.&nbsp;Messier has served on the board of directors of Rentabiliweb Group since May 2011. After graduating from the French university, Ecole Polytechnique,
	Mr.&nbsp;Messier attended the Ecole Nationale d&#146;Administration, which trains civil servants. He became Managing Partner at Lazard Fr&egrave;res in 1988, a position he held for six years. Prior to this, he was responsible for the French
	Government&#146;s Privatization plan. As such, he privatized companies among which Alcatel, Lagard&egrave;re, Saint Gobain, Suez and Soci&eacute;t&eacute; G&eacute;n&eacute;rale, now all part of the top twenty French corporations. Mr.&nbsp;Messier
	served as President of Vivendi Universal from 1994 to 2002. During these years, he founded the mobile firm Cegetel and turned Vivendi into a conglomerate focused on two core activities: utilities (water, power and transport) and communications (pay
	TV, telecoms and internet), selling off assets in other areas. Mr.&nbsp;Messier has been managing his own &#147;boutique&#148; since 2003, Messier Maris&nbsp;&amp; Associ&eacute;s, an investment bank headquartered in Paris and New York representing
	more than 50 professionals.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Investment Agreement
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On September&nbsp;14, 2011, Bpifrance Participations (formerly Fonds Strat&eacute;gique d&#146;Investissement), Mr.&nbsp;Pierre Bastid,
	Dr.&nbsp;David Sourdive, Dr.&nbsp;Andr&eacute; Choulika and the Company entered into an investment agreement, or the Investment Agreement, in connection with the investment by Bpifrance Participations and Mr.&nbsp;Pierre Bastid each of
	&#128;25&nbsp;million in Cellectis. Pursuant to the Investment Agreement, the parties, among other things, undertook to vote, as shareholders and/or as board members, in favor of (a)&nbsp;the appointment of two board members proposed by Bpifrance
	Participations (Mr. Laurent Arthaud and Dr.&nbsp;Annick Schwebig), (b)&nbsp;the appointment of one board member proposed by Mr.&nbsp;Pierre Bastid (none was appointed). The parties to the Investment Agreement terminated the agreement upon the
	listing of the ADSs on the Nasdaq Global.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	There are no family relationships among any of our executive officers or directors.

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<B>
